meaning: Movement along the demand curve to the left (higher price & lower quantity demanded).
A consumer's desire, willingness and ability to pay a price for a specific good or service.
Graph that shows the different quantity of a product demanded at different price levels.
The money available after paying taxes that you can choose how to use.
The financial ability to actually purchase the product.
Taxation on spending (VAT, excise duties, import taxes)
The amount a single person would be willing to buy at a range of prices.
Basic systems government's need to make economic activity possible, e.g. transport and communications
When one variable goes up the other variable goes down.
Total demand for a product
When a change in price causes a new point on the existing curve.
When and increase in one variable moves the entire curve to a new location
Movement along the supply curve to the left (lower price & lower quantity supplied).
When price goes up quantity supplied goes up and visa versa
The number of goods/services firms are able & willing to supply at a range of prices.
Graph that shows the different quantity of a product supplied at different price levels.
Changing quickly and suddenly
The point at which quantity demanded and quantities supplied are equal.
Where quantity demanded of a good or service exceeds supply, resulting in shortages and higher prices.
Where quantity supplied of a good or service exceeds supply, resulting in shortages and higher prices.
A movement along the demand curve to the right (lower price & higher quantity demanded).
A movement along the supply curve to the right (higher price & higher quantity supplied).
Price at which the amount supplied matches the exact amount demanded.
Goods that are purchased to support/go with another product (petrol & cars).
Goods that consumers demand less of as incomes increase due to them opting to buy higher quality alternatives.
Goods for which demand will increase if incomes do or fall if incomes fall.
Goods or services that can be used to replace on another.
The responsiveness of quantity supplied or demanded in relation to changes in price/income/other products.
Where one variable (Price or quantity) is fixed and the other variable cannot change it.
When PED is greater than 1 and A % change in price results in greater % change in quantity demanded.

The responsiveness in quantity demanded to a change in price. 
Formula: % change in QD / % Change in P

When PED is less than 1 and quantity demanded is not very responsive to a change in price.
Formula: % change in Qs / % change in P
products that sell quickly at a relatively low cost
When PES is greater than 1 and quantity supplied is very responsive to a change in price.
The responsiveness in quantity supplied to a change in price.
When PES is less than 1 and quantity supplied is not very responsive to a change in price.
Substances used to make other things, e.g. Crude Oil
